content: <?xml version='1.0' encoding='UTF-8'?><modsCollection rowCount="1"><mods><identifier type="pw">fs20123133</identifier><identifier type="pwpk">70041511</identifier><identifier type="series">Fact Sheet</identifier><identifier type="seriesNumber">2012-3133</identifier><identifier type="seriesCode">FS</identifier><genre>USGS Numbered Series</genre><titleInfo><title>Wetland fire remote sensing research--The Greater Everglades example</title></titleInfo><originInfo><dateOther>Thu, 6 Dec 2012 00:00 -0600</dateOther><dateIssued>2012</dateIssued><publisher>U.S. Geological Survey</publisher><placeTerm>Reston, VA</placeTerm></originInfo><name><namePart>Jones, John W.</namePart><role>Author</role></name><abstract>Fire is a major factor in the Everglades ecosystem. For thousands of years, lightning-strike fires from summer thunderstorms have helped create and maintain a dynamic landscape suited both to withstand fire and recover quickly in the wake of frequent fires. Today, managers in the Everglades National Park are implementing controlled burns to promote healthy, sustainable vegetation patterns and ecosystem functions. The U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) is using remote sensing to improve fire-management databases in the Everglades, gain insights into post-fire land-cover dynamics, and develop spatially and temporally explicit fire-scar data for habitat and hydrologic modeling.</abstract><physicalDescription><form>2 p.; maps (col.)</form><form>U.S. Geological Survey</form><form>Reston, VA</form></physicalDescription><location><url note="THUMBNAIL">http://pubs.er.usgs.gov/thumbnails/fs_2012_3133.gif</url><url note="DOCUMENT">http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2012/3133/pdf/fs2012-3133.pdf</url><url note="INDEX PAGE">http://pubs.usgs.gov/fs/2012/3133/</url></location><note type="citation/reference">Wetland fire remote sensing research--The Greater Everglades example; 2012; FS; 2012-3133; Fact Sheet; Jones, John W.</note><languageTerm>English</languageTerm><relatedItem type="original"><titleInfo><title>Fact Sheet</title></titleInfo></relatedItem></mods></modsCollection>
